image.altText: A fire truck outside a building that is burnt on the top.

items.synopsis: Multiple people have died after a fire broke out overnight at a four-storey hostel in New Zealand's capital, Wellington, authorities have confirmed.

title.children: Fire crews face 'worst nightmare' as multiple people killed in New Zealand hostel blaze

image.altText: A hand holds large hailstones

items.synopsis: Some areas have received a month's worth of rain overnight, while Tuesday morning commuters on the M1 have been delayed by flash flooding on the Gold Coast.

title.children: Storms lash south-east Qld, dumping heavy rain and hail

image.altText: Richard Boyle

items.synopsis: It's a crisis that calls into question the wisdom of government outsourcing crucial functions and highlights the often cosy relationship between government, bureaucracy, regulators and the corporate world, writes Ian Verrender.

title.children: Richard Boyle faces life behind bars while those in the PwC scandal are protected by the corporate world

image.altText: Two dinosaurs running through a small forrest on a spinning rock graphic.

title.children: How experts are solving the mystery of Queensland's famous Lark Quarry dinosaur trackways

image.altText: Dr Janin Bredehoeft 1

items.synopsis: An embarrassing day is coming for Australian businesses that have a large gender pay gap, with the data from individual organisations to be made public.

image.altText: a skyline with houses

items.synopsis: The Sunshine Coast Council, frustrated over the housing shortage as its population booms, takes planning matters into its own hands and pushes for state and federal support.

title.children: Advocates say council plan to speed up affordable housing construction could provide national blueprint

image.altText: A Red Rooster store and a Cold Rock store

title.children: Two fast food businesses hit with hundreds of charges for allegedly failing to comply with child labour laws

image.altText: Two naval officers on the bridge of a naval ship.

items.synopsis: Two of the Royal Australian Navy's longest-serving ships have kissed the wharf for the final time on duty.

title.children: Emotional farewell as navy ships drop anchor after life of service

image.altText: a woman in high-vis workwear standing next to a crate full of old computers and TVs

title.children: Natasha can pull apart and recycle 97 per cent of your TV, but e-waste is still swamping Australia

image.altText: A young man in a blue shirt laughing with trees in the background

items.synopsis: Outback Way is famed for being "Australia's longest shortcut", but in recent years its Warakurna Roadhouse has earned its own reputation as a must stop for another reason — jokes.

title.children: This roadhouse is now a 'must visit' thanks to a local larrikin and his dad jokes

image.altText: The 'big four'

title.children: Banks sign up to anti-scam platform to put 'immediate halt' to trick transfers

image.altText: A man holds up a black lizard with yellow dots and a light blue tail.

items.synopsis: Tour operator Max Jackson said the monitor lizard, which was rarely spotted in Australia, was a calm juvenile that allowed him to interact with it.

title.children: Queensland tour operator with 'the shakes' after friendly encounter with rarely seen blue-tailed monitor

image.altText: a man standing outdoors on a paddock with cows behind him and wearing a cap and looking out over the land

title.children: Alastair lost his business due to pollution from toxic foam — but he won't get a cent from a class action payout

image.altText: A black and white image of a dam that has been blown apart.

items.synopsis: Today marks 80 years since the Dambusters Raid during World War II, a mission so secretive the crew didn't even know their target until the night before.

title.children: On this day 80 years ago one of the most important flying missions of WWII took place under the cover of darkness

image.altText: A tall tower under construction with sculptures in the foreground

items.synopsis: SA Police say the man ran and jumped from the Festival Plaza concourse, fell several metres onto the ground below and was taken to the Royal Adelaide Hospital in a critical condition.

title.children: Man in critical condition after jumping from Adelaide Festival Plaza balcony

image.altText: A composite image of three women. One of the women holds a baby.

items.synopsis: Hopes, dreams, and disappointment. Five women aged between 24 and 41 share their stories of egg freezing.

title.children: Dreams and disappointments: Women share their stories of egg freezing

image.altText: A woman standing in front of a small house with a white picket fence with hanging flower baskets

items.synopsis: After months of assessments and reports, the NSW Reconstruction Authority says Thelma Murphy's home in a caravan park is not eligible for further disaster relief, leaving her to ask why her home is "deemed less worthy".

title.children: Thelma's home is her haven, but when it was destroyed by flood she couldn't get the same help as others

items.synopsis: Ningaloo's sparkling turquoise waters and marine life are well known to many, but this World Heritage treasure extends to the land, too — and conservationists fear its future is on a knife's edge.

title.children: This wild paradise offers a window into the past and future of our planet

image.altText: Man wearing a suit, standing next to a window.

items.synopsis: Following the release of the damning Brereton report in November 2020, Defence confirmed Army had "initiated administrative action against 17 individuals where there was an alleged failure to meet ADF expectations".

title.children: Defence insists due process was given to accused soldiers as anger grows over Afghanistan inquiry fallout

image.altText: A woman

items.synopsis: Homicide detectives have revisited the investigation into the death of Healesville woman Marea Yann in 2003. A $1 million reward for information is being offered.

title.children: The TV was still on, and Marea's purse was on the floor. Twenty years later, police are still hunting for her killer

image.altText: Ukrainian service members from a 3rd separate assault brigade of the Armed Forces of Ukraine.

items.synopsis: While the UK prime minister says his country alone cannot supply Ukraine with fighter jets, he pledges to support Volodymyr Zelenskyy in the creation of a "jets coalition" between allies.

title.children: Ukraine claims battlefield gains in Bakhmut as Zelenskky's Europe tour secures more weapons

image.altText: Donald Trump in blue suit and red tie speaking at podium with US flag in the background.

items.synopsis: The FBI lacked evidence to investigate Donald Trump's 2016 presidential campaign and relied too heavily on tips provided by Mr Trump's political opponents to fuel the probe, US Special Counsel John Durham concluded in a report released on Monday.

title.children: FBI lacked evidence for alleged Trump-Russia collusion probe, US Special Counsel finds

image.altText: A child rides a bike on a track with jumps and berms.

items.synopsis: Halls Creek is battling entrenched social issues but leaders say children are flocking to use a new BMX pump track, seen as just the beginning of plans to make the town more liveable.

title.children: 'Stagnated' outback town turns to sport and recreation to drive down youth crime

image.altText: drone shot of beach with turquoise water, rocks, sand, and greenery.

items.synopsis: It's called Denmark but its residents have an Australian accent? Meet the tiny town reaching out to its namesake ahead of the 2023 FIFA Women's World Cup in Perth.

title.children: WA town of Denmark invites Princess Mary to visit ahead of FIFA Women's World Cup

image.altText: A man stands in front of red and green indicator boards.

items.synopsis: The Australian share market has begun its day lower, after modest overnight gains on Wall Street amid concerns about a slowing US economy and wavering optimism over a debt ceiling deal in Washington.

title.children: ASX slips, Wall Street rises as US debt ceiling debate drags on

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Losses across the healthcare, consumer staples and utilities sectors dragged the Australian share market lower on Tuesday morning. The ASX 200 was down 0.2% to 7,250 points, by 10:35am AEST. 150 stocks out of 200 stocks were lower, with supermarket giants Coles and Woolworths and biotech company CSL down by around 1.2% each. Today's worst performing stocks include Elders (-3.8%), PEXA (-2%), Lifestyle Communities (-3.2%) and West African Resources (-3%). Materials and financials were the best performing sectors, led by gains from Allkem (+1.3%), Macquarie Group (+0.9%) and Sandfire Resources (+1.2%). Shares of James Hardie Industries jumped 8.3% after the company forcast a higher quarterly profit. The building matierals company said it expects to report adjusted net income in the range of $US145 million to $US165 million for the first quarter of the 2024 fiscal year. That compares with a profit $US154.3 million in the year-earlier period and consensus estimate of $US137 million, according to UBS analysts.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Healthcare and consumer stocks weigh on ASX

children.content: Losses across the healthcare, consumer staples and utilities sectors dragged the Australian share market lower on Tuesday morning.
The ASX 200 was down 0.2% to 7,250 points, by 10:35am AEST.
150 stocks out of 200 stocks were lower, with supermarket giants Coles and Woolworths and biotech company CSL down by around 1.2% each.
Today's worst performing stocks include Elders (-3.8%), PEXA (-2%), Lifestyle Communities (-3.2%) and West African Resources (-3%).
Materials and financials were the best performing sectors, led by gains from Allkem (+1.3%), Macquarie Group (+0.9%) and Sandfire Resources (+1.2%).
Shares of James Hardie Industries jumped 8.3% after the company forcast a higher quarterly profit.
The building matierals company said it expects to report adjusted net income in the range of $US145 million to $US165 million for the first quarter of the 2024 fiscal year.
That compares with a profit $US154.3 million in the year-earlier period and consensus estimate of $US137 million, according to UBS analysts.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Consumers are feeling incredibly pessimistic, acccording to the latest ANZ-Roy Morgan report. Last week, consumer sentiment fell to 75.9 points (after a 1.8-point drop). A score below 100 means the pessimists outweigh the optimists. This is its lowest level since April 2020, around the early days of the COVID-19 pandemic, closed international borders and widespread lockdowns. ANZ senior economist Adelaide Timbrell said this was the 11th straight week that consumer confidence has remained below 80 points (a very pessimistic level). This research shows the Reserve Bank's decision to lift interest rates 11 times (in one year) is having an impact on consumer behaviour.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Consumer confidence sinks to lowest since April 2020

children.content: Consumers are feeling incredibly pessimistic, acccording to the latest ANZ-Roy Morgan report.
Last week, consumer sentiment fell to
75.9 points
(after a 1.8-point drop).
A score below 100 means the pessimists outweigh the optimists.
This is its lowest level since
April 2020
, around the early days of the COVID-19 pandemic, closed international borders and widespread lockdowns.
ANZ senior economist
Adelaide Timbrell
said this was the 11th straight week that consumer confidence has remained below 80 points (a very pessimistic level).
This research shows the Reserve Bank's decision to lift interest rates 11 times (in one year) is having an impact on consumer behaviour.

props.alt: A line graph showing a sharp fall in consumer confidence.

children.content: Consumer confidence has fallen to a three-year low.
(ANZ, Roy Morgan)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Richard Boyle faces the grim prospect of life in prison. In March, the former ATO employee lost his bid to be declared immune from prosecution on 24 offences stemming from his decision to go public on what he claims were unethical tactics used by his former employer to collect debts. His plight has highlighted the stark difference in justice meted out to those acting alone as opposed to those protected by the veil of the corporate world. Ironically, Mr Boyle's Federal Court decision came just weeks after Peter Collins, the former senior tax partner at accounting giant PwC, was barred from practising by the Tax Practitioners Board. His misdeed? It was discovered that in 2014, Mr Collins had shared confidential tax information with other partners and staff about a federal government initiative to clamp down on multinational tax avoidance. Ever since the Tax Practitioners Board decision in January, the firm has been desperately trying to contain the damage, hosing down concerns from within and outside the firm. But to no avail. In the past fortnight, the firm has been plunged into a crisis that threatens its very future in Australia. For more on this, here's the latest analysis from business editor Ian Verrender :
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: The dirty business behind the PwC tax scandal

featuredLink.title: Richard Boyle faces life behind bars while those in the PwC scandal are protected by the corporate world

children.content: Richard Boyle faces the grim prospect of life in prison.

In March, the former ATO employee lost his bid to be declared immune from prosecution on 24 offences stemming from his decision to go public on what he claims were unethical tactics used by his former employer to collect debts.
His plight has highlighted the stark difference in justice meted out to those acting alone as opposed to those protected by the veil of the corporate world.
Ironically, Mr Boyle's Federal Court decision came just weeks after
Peter Collins
, the former senior tax partner at accounting giant
PwC
, was barred from practising by the Tax Practitioners Board.
His misdeed? It was discovered that in 2014,
Mr Collins had shared confidential tax information with other partners and staff about a federal government initiative to clamp down on multinational tax avoidance.
Ever since the Tax Practitioners Board decision in January, the firm has been desperately trying to contain the damage, hosing down concerns from within and outside the firm. But to no avail.
In the past fortnight, the firm has been plunged into a crisis that threatens its very future in Australia.
For more on this, here's the latest analysis from business editor
Ian Verrender

image.altText: Deaclan Crowley standing outside Foodbank.

items.synopsis: Many Australians rely on cheaper food to get by, and new data shows an increase in people are accessing help from food charities for the first time.

title.children: Deaclan is seeking food relief for the first time in his life. He's part of a growing group of Australians

image.altText: A woman sitting at a table looking serious.

items.synopsis: Home owner Katy says she's been struggling to meet her loan demands, and fears losing her home. What are the steps between missing a payment and losing your property?

title.children: Australians selling investment properties, refinancing mortgages 'at a rate never before seen'

image.altText: Microsoft logo in front of scenes from video games Call of Duty, World of Warcraft and Candy Crush

title.children: Europe backs Microsoft's deal to buy Call of Duty maker Activision Blizzard, but still faces legal challenges

image.altText: A skate lying on the seabed.

items.synopsis: Researchers say Tanya Plibersek's pledge of no new extinctions is under serious threat as the only known population of an endangered ancient Tasmania ray continues to nose dive.

title.children: 'They're just not there': A rare, ancient Australian skate is on thin ice as populations plunge

image.altText: A man with fair hair and skin, wearing a suit jacket and an open-necked shirt.

items.synopsis: A former fly-in fly-out worker is found guilty of raping a colleague at a remote mine site in WA, in a case that came to the public's attention amid wide-ranging allegations of sexual assaults and harassment within the mining industry.

title.children: Victim's family sob in court as FIFO worker found guilty of raping colleague at remote mine site

image.altText: A collection of Chiang Kai-shek statues lumped together in a park

items.synopsis: Taiwan is littered with monuments to one of its most divisive leaders. However, as efforts to remove them stall, some activists to are taking matters into their own hands.

title.children: Statues of a 'ruthless' dictator are all over Taiwan. His critics keep dumping them in this park
